awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Novel Measurement of Shear Strength Evolution in Liquefied Soil and Calibration of a Fluid Dynamics-based Constitutive Model for Flow Liquefaction
awd_abstract_narration:
Countless hydraulic fill and tailings dams, levees, and other slopes contain loose soils with little or no internal cohesion.  This state renders them vulnerable to failures under seismic events in which the soil becomes "liquefied."  Although large flow failures of such earth structures are uncommon, the catastrophic consequences of such failures dramatically elevate the associated risk.  Modeling this behavior requires reliable estimates of how the strength of a liquefying soil evolves to its minimum as internal water pressures are generated during an earthquake.  Of equal importance is understanding how the soil subsequently regains its strength as water pressures dissipate once shaking ceases.  To date, there are no full-scale field measurements of this strength evolution to guide model development; therefore, engineers must rely on strength estimates calculated after the fact from sparse, poorly documented flow failure case histories.  The uncertainty in selecting design values of residual strength is exacerbated if the soil contains significant amount of fine particles, as each empirical method suggests a different approach to account for fines.  This project will provide practicing engineers a better understanding of the large-strain behavior of liquefiable soils, improved estimates of residual shear strength, and new calibrated modeling tools that are required to make crucial decisions on high-risk, high-consequence projects involving tens or even hundreds of millions of dollars. The project's education and technology transfer plan includes training and mentoring graduate and undergraduate students from multiple disciplines (geotechnical, mechanical, and electrical engineering, as well as fluid dynamics).

This interdisciplinary project centers on developing a potentially transformative understanding of the shearing resistance of liquefiable soils (including its evolution during pore pressure generation, residual strength mobilization, and pore pressure dissipation) in an environment with greater realism than available in conventional laboratory tests.  Specifically, novel centrifuge models will utilize a thin metal coupon (plate) pulled through a liquefiable soil before, during, and after shaking to directly measure the soil's residual strength and strength recovery. By embedding a pressure transducer in the coupon, it will be possible for the first time to measure pore pressures directly on the shearing surface in a liquefied soil.  The large number of measurements will allow the researchers to explore the effects of fines content (soil compressibility), effective stress, and strain rate on residual strength.  Cone penetration resistance and shear wave velocity will be measured in-situ in the centrifuge models, allowing the researchers to validate or improve empirical residual strength correlations.  In turn, the physical measurements from the centrifuge testing program will enable the researchers to calibrate a multi-disciplinary, fluid dynamics-based stress-strain constitutive model for evaluating liquefaction problems such as flow slides, debris flows and lateral spreading around pile foundations.  This project will utilize the NHERI Centrifuge facility at the University of California, Davis.

por.por_cntn:
Countless hydraulic fill and tailings dams, levees, and other slopes contain loose, granular soils, rendering them vulnerable to seismic liquefaction failures. Although flow failures are uncommon, their potentially catastrophic consequences dramatically elevate the associated risk. Modeling this behavior requires reliable estimates of the strength of the liquefied soil, how it is mobilized, and how it changes, if it does, depending on how fast the liquefied soil mass moves. However, there are no full-scale field measurements available to answer these questions. As a result, engineers must rely on the estimated strengths of liquefied soils back-calculated from sparse, poorly documented flow failure case histories.

In the experimental aspect of this project, the shear strength of liquefied soil was estimated by pulling a thin, metal plate (76.2 x 25.4 x 3.5 mm) at various speeds through saturated sand specimens that were cyclically loaded to cause liquefaction. The force required to pull the plate was measured and used to calculate the strength of the liquefied soil. Multiple soil specimens were prepared at a loose density. Some specimens were contained in a rectangular box (775 x 305 x 305 mm) and shaken using a shake table onboard the geotechnical centrifuge at the University of California at Davis. The centrifuge generates stresses in the soil specimens similar to the stresses generated in field soil deposits. Other soil specimens were cylindrical in shape (150 mm in diameter and 300 mm high) and made to liquefy in a specially designed (as part of this project) cyclic triaxial apparatus at the University of Vermont. These specimens were contained in a large cell filled with water, which was pressurized to simulate high stress levels similar to field soil deposits. Both sets of experiments required custom-designed motor-pulley-torque transducer assemblies to pull the metal plate through the liquefied soil specimens and measure the pulling force. The plate also incorporated a miniature pressure transducer that enabled, for the first time, measurements of porewater pressures directly within the failure zone. A third set of experiments were performed using a constant-volume direct simple shear apparatus at the University of Illinois at Urbana Champaign to examine the effects of strain rate (often caused by large movements associated with flow failures) on the shear strength of liquefied soils.

The project also had two significant analytical components. The first explored treating the liquefied soil as a viscous liquid and using computational fluid dynamics (CFD) concepts to simulate the experimental measurements. Two- and three-dimensional CFD models were developed. The second analytical component involved the back-analysis of 13 new flow failure case histories found in the recent literature and combining them with 58 published case histories.

The following significant outcomes were achieved contributing to the intellectual merit of this research:

  1. The liquefied shear strengths determined in the laboratory were found to be in reasonable agreement with those estimated from flow failure case histories analysis.
  2. The laboratory results indicated that the liquefied shear strength depended on the flow speed. CFD model parameters were derived from those test results. Dimensionless mechanics-based parameters were introduced to explain the physics behind the experimental observations.
  3. Two mechanics-based, statistically-sound predictive models for estimating in-situ liquefied shear strength were developed.
  4. Soil mechanics and fluid mechanics approaches were employed to understand the liquefied soil behavior, particularly the dependence of mobilized shear strength on flow speed.
  5. The CFD simulations revealed that 3D objects pulled through liquefied soils should be modeled as 3D objects and not be approximated in 2D, as often had been done in previous studies.
  6. A genetic algorithm-based multi-objective optimization framework was developed to optimize the CFD model parameters that represent the laboratory data.

The broader impact of this research includes:

  1. Geotechnical engineering practitioners are provided with a better understanding of the large-strain behavior of liquefiable soils and improved estimates of the shear strength of liquefied soils that are required to make crucial decisions on high-risk, high-consequence projects involving tens or even hundreds of millions of dollars.
  2. The CFD-based modeling could be applied to analyze a variety of problems outside of geotechnical (and geotechnical earthquake) engineering that involve strain-softening materials.
  3. The project engaged two doctoral and two undergraduate students, who had the opportunity to engage in this multidisciplinary project.
  4. A specialized, large-scale cyclic triaxial device that accommodates a metal plate (with an embedded pore pressure transducer) pulling assembly was designed and fabricated, adding to the facilities at the University of Vermont.
  5. A new, rigid container was designed and fabricated as part of this project. This container is now available for the users of the Center for Geotechnical Modeling at the University of California at Davis.
  6. Technical articles on this research are being published and the experimental and numerical data generated in this project are being reposited in DesignSafe.

Last Modified: 05/02/2023
Modified by: Mandar Dewoolkar
por.por_txt_cntn:
Countless hydraulic fill and tailings dams, levees, and other slopes contain loose, granular soils, rendering them vulnerable to seismic liquefaction failures. Although flow failures are uncommon, their potentially catastrophic consequences dramatically elevate the associated risk. Modeling this behavior requires reliable estimates of the strength of the liquefied soil, how it is mobilized, and how it changes, if it does, depending on how fast the liquefied soil mass moves. However, there are no full-scale field measurements available to answer these questions. As a result, engineers must rely on the estimated strengths of liquefied soils back-calculated from sparse, poorly documented flow failure case histories.

In the experimental aspect of this project, the shear strength of liquefied soil was estimated by pulling a thin, metal plate (76.2 x 25.4 x 3.5 mm) at various speeds through saturated sand specimens that were cyclically loaded to cause liquefaction. The force required to pull the plate was measured and used to calculate the strength of the liquefied soil. Multiple soil specimens were prepared at a loose density. Some specimens were contained in a rectangular box (775 x 305 x 305 mm) and shaken using a shake table onboard the geotechnical centrifuge at the University of California at Davis. The centrifuge generates stresses in the soil specimens similar to the stresses generated in field soil deposits. Other soil specimens were cylindrical in shape (150 mm in diameter and 300 mm high) and made to liquefy in a specially designed (as part of this project) cyclic triaxial apparatus at the University of Vermont. These specimens were contained in a large cell filled with water, which was pressurized to simulate high stress levels similar to field soil deposits. Both sets of experiments required custom-designed motor-pulley-torque transducer assemblies to pull the metal plate through the liquefied soil specimens and measure the pulling force. The plate also incorporated a miniature pressure transducer that enabled, for the first time, measurements of porewater pressures directly within the failure zone. A third set of experiments were performed using a constant-volume direct simple shear apparatus at the University of Illinois at Urbana Champaign to examine the effects of strain rate (often caused by large movements associated with flow failures) on the shear strength of liquefied soils.

The project also had two significant analytical components. The first explored treating the liquefied soil as a viscous liquid and using computational fluid dynamics (CFD) concepts to simulate the experimental measurements. Two- and three-dimensional CFD models were developed. The second analytical component involved the back-analysis of 13 new flow failure case histories found in the recent literature and combining them with 58 published case histories.

The following significant outcomes were achieved contributing to the intellectual merit of this research:

The liquefied shear strengths determined in the laboratory were found to be in reasonable agreement with those estimated from flow failure case histories analysis. 
The laboratory results indicated that the liquefied shear strength depended on the flow speed. CFD model parameters were derived from those test results. Dimensionless mechanics-based parameters were introduced to explain the physics behind the experimental observations.
Two mechanics-based, statistically-sound predictive models for estimating in-situ liquefied shear strength were developed.
Soil mechanics and fluid mechanics approaches were employed to understand the liquefied soil behavior, particularly the dependence of mobilized shear strength on flow speed.
The CFD simulations revealed that 3D objects pulled through liquefied soils should be modeled as 3D objects and not be approximated in 2D, as often had been done in previous studies. 
A genetic algorithm-based multi-objective optimization framework was developed to optimize the CFD model parameters that represent the laboratory data. 


The broader impact of this research includes:

Geotechnical engineering practitioners are provided with a better understanding of the large-strain behavior of liquefiable soils and improved estimates of the shear strength of liquefied soils that are required to make crucial decisions on high-risk, high-consequence projects involving tens or even hundreds of millions of dollars.
The CFD-based modeling could be applied to analyze a variety of problems outside of geotechnical (and geotechnical earthquake) engineering that involve strain-softening materials.
The project engaged two doctoral and two undergraduate students, who had the opportunity to engage in this multidisciplinary project.
A specialized, large-scale cyclic triaxial device that accommodates a metal plate (with an embedded pore pressure transducer) pulling assembly was designed and fabricated, adding to the facilities at the University of Vermont. 
A new, rigid container was designed and fabricated as part of this project. This container is now available for the users of the Center for Geotechnical Modeling at the University of California at Davis.
Technical articles on this research are being published and the experimental and numerical data generated in this project are being reposited in DesignSafe.
